t: Matthew 13
The Parable of the Sower
On*p that day Jesus went out of the house and was sitting by the sea.
Such large crowds gathered around him that he got into a boat and sat down, while the whole crowd stood on the shore.
Then*p he told them many things in parables, saying, “Consider*r the*r sower*r who*r went*r out*r to*r sow.*r
As*r he*r sowed,*r some*r seed*r fell*r along*r the*r path,*r and*r the*r birds*r came*r and*r devoured*r them.*r
Other*r seed*r fell*r on*r rocky*r ground*r where*r it*r didn’t*r have*r much*r soil,*r and*r it*r grew*r up*r quickly*r since*r the*r soil*r wasn’t*r deep.*r
But*r when*r the*r sun*r came*r up,*r it*r was*r scorched,*r and*r since*r it*r had*r no*r root,*r it*r withered*r away.*r
Other*r seed*r fell*r among*r thorns,*r and*r the*r thorns*r came*r up*r and*r choked*r it.*r
Still*r other*r seed*r fell*r on*r good*r ground*r and*r produced*r fruit:*r some*r a*r hundred,*r some*r sixty,*r and*r some*r thirty*r times*r what*r was*r sown.*r
Let*r anyone*r who*r has*r ears*r listen.”*r
Why Jesus Used Parables
Then*p the disciples came up and asked him, “Why are you speaking to them in parables?”
He*p answered, “Because*r the*r secrets*r of*r the*r kingdom*r of*r heaven*r have*r been*r given*r for*r you*r to*r know,*r but*r it*r has*r not*r been*r given*r to*r them.*r

For*r whoever*r has,*r more*r will*r be*r given*r to*r him,*r and*r he*r will*r have*r more*r than*r enough;*r but*r whoever*r does*r not*r have,*r even*r what*r he*r has*r will*r be*r taken*r away*r from*r him.*r
That*r is*r why*r I*r speak*r to*r them*r in*r parables,*r because*r looking*r they*r do*r not*r see,*r and*r hearing*r they*r do*r not*r listen*r or*r understand.*r

Isaiah’s*r prophecy*r is*r fulfilled*r in*r them,*r which*r says:*r You*irpn will*ir listen*ir and*ir listen,*ir but*irln never*ir understand;*ir you*irln will*ir look*ir and*ir look,*ir but*irln never*ir perceive.*ir

For*irln this*ir people’s*ir heart*ir has*ir grown*ir callous;*ir their*irln ears*ir are*ir hard*ir of*ir hearing,*ir and*irln they*ir have*ir shut*ir their*ir eyes;*ir otherwise*irln they*ir might*ir see*ir with*ir their*ir eyes,*ir and*irln hear*ir with*ir their*ir ears,*ir and*ir understand*irln with*ir their*ir hearts,*ir and*irln turn*ir back —*ir and*irln I*ir would*ir heal*ir them.*ir
“Blessed*rp are*r your*r eyes*r because*r they*r do*r see,*r and*r your*r ears*r because*r they*r do*r hear.*r

For*r truly*r I*r tell*r you,*r many*r prophets*r and*r righteous*r people*r longed*r to*r see*r the*r things*r you*r see*r but*r didn’t*r see*r them,*r to*r hear*r the*r things*r you*r hear*r but*r didn’t*r hear*r them.*r
The Parable of the Sower Explained
“So*rp listen*r to*r the*r parable*r of*r the*r sower:*r

When*r anyone*r hears*r the*r word*r about*r the*r kingdom*r and*r doesn’t*r understand*r it,*r the*r evil*r one*r comes*r and*r snatches*r away*r what*r was*r sown*r in*r his*r heart.*r This*r is*r the*r one*r sown*r along*r the*r path.*r
And*r the*r one*r sown*r on*r rocky*r ground -*r this*r is*r one*r who*r hears*r the*r word*r and*r immediately*r receives*r it*r with*r joy.*r
But*r he*r has*r no*r root*r and*r is*r short-lived.*r When*r distress*r or*r persecution*r comes*r because*r of*r the*r word,*r immediately*r he*r falls*r away.*r

Now*r the*r one*r sown*r among*r the*r thorns -*r this*r is*r one*r who*r hears*r the*r word,*r but*r the*r worries*r of*r this*r age*r and*r the*r deceitfulness*r of*r wealth*r choke*r the*r word,*r and*r it*r becomes*r unfruitful.*r

But*r the*r one*r sown*r on*r the*r good*r ground -*r this*r is*r one*r who*r hears*r and*r understands*r the*r word,*r who*r does*r produce*r fruit*r and*r yields:*r some*r a*r hundred,*r some*r sixty,*r some*r thirty*r times*r what*r was*r sown.”*r
The Parable of the Wheat and the Weeds
He*p presented another parable to them: “The*r kingdom*r of*r heaven*r may*r be*r compared*r to*r a*r man*r who*r sowed*r good*r seed*r in*r his*r field.*r
But*r while*r people*r were*r sleeping,*r his*r enemy*r came,*r sowed*r weeds*r among*r the*r wheat,*r and*r left.*r
When*r the*r plants*r sprouted*r and*r produced*r grain,*r then*r the*r weeds*r also*r appeared.*r
The*r landowner’s*r servants*r came*r to*r him*r and*r said,*r ‘Master,*r didn’t*r you*r sow*r good*r seed*r in*r your*r field?*r Then*r where*r did*r the*r weeds*r come*r from?’*r
“‘An*rp enemy*r did*r this,’*r he*r told*r them.*r “‘So,*rp do*r you*r want*r us*r to*r go*r and*r pull*r them*r up? ’*r the*r servants*r asked*r him.*r
“‘No,’*rp he*r said.*r ‘When*r you*r pull*r up*r the*r weeds,*r you*r might*r also*r uproot*r the*r wheat*r with*r them.*r

Let*r both*r grow*r together*r until*r the*r harvest.*r At*r harvest*r time*r I’ll*r tell*r the*r reapers:*r Gather*r the*r weeds*r first*r and*r tie*r them*r in*r bundles*r to*r burn*r them,*r but*r collect*r the*r wheat*r in*r my*r barn.’”*r
The Parables of the Mustard Seed and of the Leaven
He*p presented another parable to them: “The*r kingdom*r of*r heaven*r is*r like*r a*r mustard*r seed*r that*r a*r man*r took*r and*r sowed*r in*r his*r field.*r

It’s*r the*r smallest*r of*r all*r the*r seeds,*r but*r when*r grown,*r it’s*r taller*r than*r the*r garden*r plants*r and*r becomes*r a*r tree,*r so*r that*r the*r birds*r of*r the*r sky*r come*r and*r nest*r in*r its*r branches.”*r

He*p told them another parable: “The*r kingdom*r of*r heaven*r is*r like*r leaven*r that*r a*r woman*r took*r and*r mixed*r into*r fifty*r pounds*r of*r flour*r until*r all*r of*r it*r was*r leavened.”*r
Using Parables Fulfills Prophecy
Jesus*p told the crowds all these things in parables, and he did not tell them anything without a parable,

so that what was spoken through the prophet might be fulfilled: I*ipn will*i open*i my*i mouth*i in*i parables;*i I*iln will*i declare*i things*i kept*i secret*i from*iln the*i foundation*i of the world.
Jesus Interprets the Parable of the Wheat and the Weeds
Then*p he left the crowds and went into the house. His disciples approached him and said, “Explain to us the parable of the weeds in the field.”
He*p replied, “The*r one*r who*r sows*r the*r good*r seed*r is*r the*r Son*r of*r Man;*r
the*r field*r is*r the*r world;*r and*r the*r good*r seed -*r these*r are*r the*r children*r of*r the*r kingdom.*r The*r weeds*r are*r the*r children*r of*r the*r evil*r one,*r
and*r the*r enemy*r who*r sowed*r them*r is*r the*r devil.*r The*r harvest*r is*r the*r end*r of*r the*r age,*r and*r the*r harvesters*r are*r angels.*r
Therefore,*r just*r as*r the*r weeds*r are*r gathered*r and*r burned*r in*r the*r fire,*r so*r it*r will*r be*r at*r the*r end*r of*r the*r age.*r
The*r Son*r of*r Man*r will*r send*r out*r his*r angels,*r and*r they*r will*r gather*r from*r his*r kingdom*r all*r who*r cause*r sin*r and*r those*r guilty*r of*r lawlessness.*r
They*r will*r throw*r them*r into*r the*r blazing*r furnace*r where*r there*r will*r be*r weeping*r and*r gnashing*r of*r teeth.*r
Then*r the*r righteous*r will*r shine*r like*r the*r sun*r in*r their*r Father’s*r kingdom.*r Let*r anyone*r who*r has*r ears*r listen.*r
The Parables of the Hidden Treasure and of the Priceless Pearl

“The*rp kingdom*r of*r heaven*r is*r like*r treasure,*r buried*r in*r a*r field,*r that*r a*r man*r found*r and*r reburied.*r Then*r in*r his*r joy*r he*r goes*r and*r sells*r everything*r he*r has*r and*r buys*r that*r field.*r
“Again,*rp the*r kingdom*r of*r heaven*r is*r like*r a*r merchant*r in*r search*r of*r fine*r pearls.*r
When*r he*r found*r one*r priceless*r pearl,*r he*r went*r and*r sold*r everything*r he*r had*r and*r bought*r it.*r
The Parable of the Net
“Again,*rp the*r kingdom*r of*r heaven*r is*r like*r a*r large*r net*r thrown*r into*r the*r sea.*r It*r collected*r every*r kind*r of*r fish,*r
and*r when*r it*r was*r full,*r they*r dragged*r it*r ashore,*r sat*r down,*r and*r gathered*r the*r good*r fish*r into*r containers,*r but*r threw*r out*r the*r worthless*r ones.*r
So*r it*r will*r be*r at*r the*r end*r of*r the*r age.*r The*r angels*r will*r go*r out,*r separate*r the*r evil*r people*r from*r the*r righteous,*r
and*r throw*r them*r into*r the*r blazing*r furnace,*r where*r there*r will*r be*r weeping*r and*r gnashing*r of*r teeth.*r
The Storehouse of Truth
“Have*rp you*r understood*r all*r these*r things?”*r They*p answered him, “Yes.”

“Therefore,”*rp he said to them, “every*r teacher*r of*r the*r law*r who*r has*r become*r a*r disciple*r in*r the*r kingdom*r of*r heaven*r is*r like*r the*r owner*r of*r a*r house*r who*r brings*r out*r of*r his*r storeroom*r treasures*r new*r and*r old.”*r
Rejection at Nazareth
When*p Jesus had finished these parables, he left there.
He went to his hometown and began to teach them in their synagogue, so that they were astonished and said, “Where did this man get this wisdom and these miraculous powers?
Isn’t this the carpenter’s son? Isn’t his mother called Mary, and his brothers James, Joseph, Simon, and Judas?
And his sisters, aren’t they all with us? So where does he get all these things?”
And they were offended by him. Jesus*p said to them, “A*r prophet*r is*r not*r without*r honor*r except*r in*r his*r hometown*r and*r in*r his*r household.”*r
And he did not do many miracles there because of their unbelief.
